remixlab.remixcam.core
Class GLFrame

java.lang.Object
  remixlab.remixcam.core.GLFrame
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
InteractiveFrame
public class GLFrame
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

A Frame is a 3D coordinate system, represented by a position() and an orientation(). The order of these transformations is important: the Frame is first translated and then rotated around the new translated origin.

Constructor Detail

GLFrame

public GLFrame()
Creates a default Frame.

Its position() is (0,0,0) and it has an identity orientation() Quaternion. The referenceFrame() and the constraint() are null.

GLFrame

public GLFrame(Vector3D p,
               Quaternion r)
Creates a Frame with a position() and an orientation().

See the Vector3D and Quaternion documentations for convenient constructors and methods.

The Frame is defined in the world coordinate system (its referenceFrame() is null). It has a null associated constraint().

GLFrame

other - the Frame containing the object to be copied

See Also:
GLFrame(GLFrame)

clone

public GLFrame clone()
Implementation of the clone method.

The method performs a deep copy of the translation() and rotation() objects of the Frame, and a shallow copy of its referenceFrame() and constraint() objects.

Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object
See Also:
copy()

translation

public final Vector3D translation()
Returns the Frame translation, defined with respect to the referenceFrame().

Use position() to get the result in the world coordinates. These two values are identical when the referenceFrame() is null (default).

See Also:
setTranslation(Vector3D), setTranslationWithConstraint(Vector3D)

rotation

public final Quaternion rotation()
Returns the Frame rotation, defined with respect to the referenceFrame() (i.e, the current Quaternion orientation).

Use orientation() to get the result in the world coordinates. These two values are identical when the referenceFrame() is null (default).

See Also:
setRotation(Quaternion), setRotationWithConstraint(Quaternion)

referenceFrame

public final GLFrame referenceFrame()
Returns the reference Frame, in which coordinates system the Frame is defined.

The translation() rotation() of the Frame are defined with respect to the reference Frame coordinate system. A null reference Frame (default value) means that the Frame is defined in the world coordinate system.

Use position() and orientation() to recursively convert values along the reference Frame chain and to get values expressed in the world coordinate system. The values match when the reference Frame null.

Use setReferenceFrame(GLFrame) to set this value and create a Frame hierarchy. Convenient functions allow you to convert 3D coordinates from one Frame to another: see coordinatesOf(Vector3D), localCoordinatesOf(Vector3D) , coordinatesOfIn(Vector3D, GLFrame) and their inverse functions.

Vectors can also be converted using transformOf(Vector3D), transformOfIn(Vector3D, GLFrame), localTransformOf(Vector3D) and their inverse functions.

constraint

public Constraint constraint()
Returns the current constraint applied to the Frame.

A null value (default) means that no Constraint is used to filter the Frame translation and rotation.

See the Constraint class documentation for details.

listeners

public java.util.List<KeyFrameInterpolator> listeners()
Returns the list of KeyFrameInterpolators that are currently listening to this frame. Normally, you should not call this method as the KeyFrameInterpolator takes care of calling it.

See Also:
KeyFrameInterpolator.addKeyFrame(GLFrame, float, boolean)

See Also:

Use setPosition(Vector3D) to define the world coordinates position(). Use setTranslationWithConstraint(Vector3D) to take into account the potential constraint() of the Frame.

setReferenceFrame

public final void setReferenceFrame(GLFrame rFrame)
Sets the referenceFrame() of the Frame and calls modified().

The Frame translation() and rotation() are then defined in the referenceFrame() coordinate system.

Use position() and orientation() to express these in the world coordinate system.

Using this method, you can create a hierarchy of Frames. This hierarchy needs to be a tree, which root is the world coordinate system (i.e., null referenceFrame()). No action is performed if setting refFrame as the referenceFrame() would create a loop in the Frame hierarchy.

See Also:
settingAsReferenceFrameWillCreateALoop(GLFrame)

setConstraint

public void setConstraint(Constraint c)
Sets the constraint() attached to the Frame.

A null value means no constraint.

settingAsReferenceFrameWillCreateALoop

public final boolean settingAsReferenceFrameWillCreateALoop(GLFrame frame)
Returns true if setting frame as the Frame's referenceFrame() would create a loop in the Frame hierarchy.

translate

public final void translate(Vector3D t)
Same as translate(t, true). Calls modified().

See Also:

translate

public final void translate(Vector3D t,
                            boolean keepArg)
Translates the Frame according to t, locally defined with respect to the referenceFrame(). Calls modified().

If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the translation actually applied to the Frame may differ from t (since it can be filtered by the constraint()). Use translate(t, false) to retrieve the filtered translation value and translate(t, true) to keep the original value of t. Use setTranslation(Vector3D) to directly translate the Frame without taking the constraint() into account.

See Also:
rotate(Quaternion)

translate

public final void translate(float x,
                            float y,
                            float z)
Same as translate(Vector3D) but with float parameters.

rotate

public final void rotate(Quaternion q)
Same as rotate(q, true). Calls modified().

See Also:
rotate(Quaternion, boolean), translate(Vector3D)

rotate

public final void rotate(Quaternion q,
                         boolean keepArg)
Rotates the Frame by q (defined in the Frame coordinate system): R = R*q. Calls modified().

If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the rotation actually applied to the Frame may differ from q (since it can be filtered by the constraint()). Use rotate(q, false) to retrieve the filtered rotation value and rotate(q, true) to keep the original value of q. Use setRotation(Quaternion) to directly rotate the Frame without taking the constraint() into account.

See Also:
translate(Vector3D)

rotate

public final void rotate(float x,
                         float y,
                         float z,
                         float w)
Same as rotate(Quaternion) but with float Quaternion parameters.

rotateAroundPoint

public final void rotateAroundPoint(Quaternion rotation,
                                    Vector3D point)
Same as rotateAroundPoint(rotation, point, true). Calls modified().

rotateAroundPoint

public final void rotateAroundPoint(Quaternion rotation,
                                    Vector3D point,
                                    boolean keepArg)
Makes the Frame rotate(Quaternion) by rotation around point. Calls modified().

point is defined in the world coordinate system, while the rotation axis is defined in the Frame coordinate system.

If the Frame has a constraint(), rotation is first constrained using Constraint.constrainRotation(Quaternion, GLFrame). Hence the rotation actually applied to the Frame may differ from rotation (since it can be filtered by the constraint()). Use rotateAroundPoint(rotation, point, false) to retrieve the filtered rotation value and rotateAroundPoint(rotation, point, true) to keep the original value of rotation.

The translation which results from the filtered rotation around point is then computed and filtered using Constraint.constrainTranslation(Vector3D, GLFrame).

alignWithFrame

public final void alignWithFrame(GLFrame frame)
Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, false, 0.85f)

alignWithFrame

public final void alignWithFrame(GLFrame frame,
                                 boolean move)
Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, move, 0.85f)

alignWithFrame

public final void alignWithFrame(GLFrame frame,
                                 float threshold)
Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, false, threshold)

alignWithFrame

public final void alignWithFrame(GLFrame frame,
                                 boolean move,
                                 float threshold)
Aligns the Frame with frame, so that two of their axis are parallel.

If one of the X, Y and Z axis of the Frame is almost parallel to any of the X, Y, or Z axis of frame, the Frame is rotated so that these two axis actually become parallel.

If, after this first rotation, two other axis are also almost parallel, a second alignment is performed. The two frames then have identical orientations, up to 90 degrees rotations.

threshold measures how close two axis must be to be considered parallel. It is compared with the absolute values of the dot product of the normalized axis.

When move is set to true, the Frame position() is also affected by the alignment. The new Frame position() is such that the frame frame position (computed with coordinatesOf(Vector3D), in the Frame coordinates system) does not change.

frame may be null and then represents the world coordinate system (same convention than for the referenceFrame()).

projectOnLine

public final void projectOnLine(Vector3D origin,
                                Vector3D direction)
Translates the Frame so that its position() lies on the line defined by origin and direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

Simply uses an orthogonal projection. direction does not need to be normalized.

inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector3D) performs the inverse conversion. transformOf(Vector3D) converts 3D vectors instead of 3D coordinates.

coordinatesOf(Vector3D) performs the inverse conversion. Use inverseTransformOf(Vector3D) to transform 3D vectors instead of 3D coordinates.

transformOf

public final Vector3D transformOf(Vector3D src)
Returns the Frame transform of a vector src defined in the world coordinate system (converts vectors from world to Frame).

inverseTransformOf(Vector3D) performs the inverse transformation. coordinatesOf(Vector3D) converts 3D coordinates instead of 3D vectors (here only the rotational part of the transformation is taken into account).

inverseTransformOf

public final Vector3D inverseTransformOf(Vector3D src)
Returns the world transform of the vector whose coordinates in the Frame coordinate system is src (converts vectors from Frame to world).

transformOf(Vector3D) performs the inverse transformation. Use inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector3D) to transform 3D coordinates instead of 3D vectors.

matrix

public final Matrix3D matrix()
Returns the Matrix3D associated with this Frame.

This method could be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify the processing modelview matrix from a Frame hierarchy. For example, with this Frame hierarchy:

Frame body = new Frame();
Frame leftArm = new Frame();
Frame rightArm = new Frame();
leftArm.setReferenceFrame(body);
rightArm.setReferenceFrame(body);

The associated processing drawing code should look like:

p.pushMatrix();//Supposing p is the PApplet instance
p.applyMatrix(body.matrix());
drawBody();
p.pushMatrix();
p.applyMatrix(leftArm.matrix());
drawArm();
p.popMatrix();
p.pushMatrix();
p.applyMatrix(rightArm.matrix());
drawArm();
p.popMatrix();
p.popMatrix();

Note the use of nested pushMatrix() and popMatrix() blocks to represent the frame hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

Attention: This technique is inefficient because p.applyMatrix will try to calculate the inverse of the transform. Avoid it whenever possible and instead apply a translation/rotation (in that order) yourself.

This matrix only represents the local Frame transformation (i.e., with respect to the referenceFrame()). Use worldMatrix() to get the full Frame transformation matrix (i.e., from the world to the Frame coordinate system). These two match when the referenceFrame() is null.

The result is only valid until the next call to matrix() or worldMatrix(). Use it immediately (as above).

Note: The scaling factor of the 4x4 matrix is 1.0.

worldMatrix

public final Matrix3D worldMatrix()
Returns the processing transformation matrix represented by the Frame.

This method should be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify the processing modelview matrix from a Frame:

// Here the modelview matrix corresponds to the world coordinate system.
Frame fr = new Frame(pos, Quaternion(from, to));
pushMatrix();
applyMatrix(worldMatrix());
// draw object in the fr coordinate system.
popMatrix();

This matrix represents the global Frame transformation: the entire referenceFrame() hierarchy is taken into account to define the Frame transformation from the world coordinate system. Use matrix() to get the local Frame transformation matrix (i.e. defined with respect to the referenceFrame()). These two match when the referenceFrame() is null.

Attention: The result is only valid until the next call to matrix() or worldMatrix(). Use it immediately (as above).

Note: The scaling factor of the 4x4 matrix is 1.0.

fromMatrix

public final void fromMatrix(Matrix3D pM)
Sets the Frame from a Matrix3D (processing matrix) representation (rotation in the upper left 3x3 matrix and translation on the last column). Calls modified().

Hence, if a code fragment looks like:

float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

It is equivalent to write:

Frame fr = new Frame();
fr.fromMatrix(m);
applyMatrix(fr.matrix());

Using this conversion, you can benefit from the powerful Frame transformation methods to translate points and vectors to and from the Frame coordinate system to any other Frame coordinate system (including the world coordinate system). See coordinatesOf(Vector3D) and transformOf(Vector3D).

Attention: A Frame does not contain a scale factor. The possible scaling in m will not be converted into the Frame by this method.

inverse

public final GLFrame inverse()
Returns a Frame representing the inverse of the Frame space transformation.

The rotation() the new Frame is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original rotation. Its translation() is the negated inverse rotated image of the original translation.

If a Frame is considered as a space rigid transformation (translation and rotation), the inverse() Frame performs the inverse transformation.

Only the local Frame transformation (i.e., defined with respect to the referenceFrame()) is inverted. Use worldInverse() for a global inverse.

The resulting Frame has the same referenceFrame() as the Frame and a null constraint().

Note: The scaling factor of the 4x4 matrix is 1.0.

worldInverse

public final GLFrame worldInverse()
Returns the inverse() of the Frame world transformation.

The orientation() of the new Frame is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original orientation. Its position() is the negated and inverse rotated image of the original position.

The result Frame has a null referenceFrame() and a null constraint().

Use inverse() for a local (i.e., with respect to referenceFrame()) transformation inverse.
